title: Complete JavaScript Guide
description: Master JavaScript from basics to advanced level with ES6+, async programming, and modern frameworks.

subsections.title: What is JavaScript?
subsections.content:
JavaScript is a versatile, lightweight, interpreted programming language designed to run in web browsers and servers.

**Key Characteristics:**
- **Dynamic Typing**: Variables can hold any data type
- **Event-Driven**: Responds to user interactions
- **Functional**: First-class functions and closures
- **Prototype-Based**: Object inheritance through prototypes
- **Asynchronous**: Supports callbacks, promises, async/await
- **Ubiquitous**: Runs everywhere - browsers, servers (Node.js), mobile

keyPoints.label: Client-Side
keyPoints.description: Runs in web browsers for interactivity

subsections.title: JavaScript Execution
subsections.content:
Source Code (.js) → JavaScript Engine → Parsing → Compilation → Execution → Output

Modern JS Engines (V8, SpiderMonkey) use JIT compilation for performance

subsections.title: Variable Declaration
subsections.explanation: Use const by default, let when reassignment needed, avoid var in modern JavaScript

subsections.title: Arithmetic Operators
subsections.code:
const a = 10, b = 3;

console.log(a + b);      // 13 (Addition)
console.log(a - b);      // 7 (Subtraction)
console.log(a * b);      // 30 (Multiplication)
console.log(a / b);      // 3.333... (Division)
console.log(a % b);      // 1 (Modulo)
console.log(a ** b);     // 1000 (Exponentiation)

// Increment/Decrement
let x = 5;
x++;                     // 6 (post-increment)
++x;                     // 7 (pre-increment)
x--;                     // 6 (post-decrement)
--x;                     // 5 (pre-decrement)
subsections.explanation: JavaScript automatically converts types in arithmetic operations (type coercion)

subsections.title: Comparison & Logical Operators
subsections.code:
// Comparison
console.log(5 == '5');      // true (loose equality, type coercion)
console.log(5 === '5');     // false (strict equality, no coercion)
console.log(5 != '5');      // false
console.log(5 !== '5');     // true
console.log(5 > 3);         // true
console.log(5 <= 5);        // true

// Logical
console.log(true && false);  // false (AND)
console.log(true || false);  // true (OR)
console.log(!true);          // false (NOT)

// Nullish Coalescing & Optional Chaining
const user = null;
console.log(user ?? 'Guest');  // 'Guest' (null/undefined)
console.log(user?.name);       // undefined (safe access)
subsections.explanation: Always use === for comparison to avoid unexpected type coercion

subsections.title: if-else & switch
subsections.explanation: Use switch for multiple conditions on same value, ternary for simple if-else

subsections.title: Loop Types
subsections.explanation: for-of for arrays/iterables, for-in for object keys, avoid for-in with arrays

subsections.title: Function Declaration & Arrow Functions
subsections.explanation: Arrow functions don't have their own 'this' context - useful for callbacks

subsections.title: Object Fundamentals
subsections.explanation: Objects are key-value pairs; use destructuring for cleaner code

subsections.title: Array Methods
subsections.explanation: Array methods are essential for functional programming in JavaScript

subsections.title: Callbacks, Promises & Async/Await
subsections.explanation: Async/await is the modern way to handle asynchronous operations - cleaner than callbacks

subsections.title: Template Literals & Destructuring
subsections.explanation: Template literals and destructuring make code more readable and concise

subsections.title: Selecting & Modifying Elements
